greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of ways to write n =  x + y (x, y > 0) with p(39, x) + p(40, y) prime, where p(m, k) denotes the m-gonal number (m-2)*k*(k-1)/2 + k.
comment: By a conjecture in A228425, we should have a(n) > 0 for all n > 1.
Conjecture: For each m = 3, 4, ..., any sufficiently large integer n can be written as x + y (x, y > 0) with p(m, x) + p(m+1, y) prime.
link: Zhi-Wei Sun, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Zhi-Wei Sun, On universal sums of polygonal numbers, preprint, arXiv:0905.0635.
results.author: _Zhi-Wei Sun_, Nov 10 2013
